speaker: Frasier
text: Hi, we're back.  Roz tells me we have Chester on the line. [_connects_] Hello, Chester.  How can I help you?

speaker: Chester
text: [_v.o._] I don't know.  I've had a lot of fights with my wife lately.  She feels I'm just wasting my life, standing still--

speaker: Frasier
text: Spinning your wheels?

speaker: Chester
text: Huh?  I don't follow.

speaker: Frasier
text: Chester, I'm afraid this problem might be just a little too complex for the few seconds we have remaining.  Uh, why don't you try to call us back tomorrow, I'll make sure that you get on first thing.

speaker: Chester
text: Gee, it's awful tough to get through.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I'll tell you what, hang tight and when I get off the air I'll pick up and try to help you then.

speaker: Chester
text: Take your time.

speaker: Frasier
text: O.K., everybody, I've got to scoot.  Bulldog's up next after the news with the Gonzo Sports Show.  Today's topic: What's wrong with our Seattle Mariners?  If you haven't had a chance to voice your opinion on that in the last eighteen years, you'll want to today!  So long, all.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, Roz, that was a pretty good show!

speaker: Roz
text: [_distracted_] Mmm-hmm.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, what are you reading so intently?

speaker: Roz
text: Oh, it's, uh, "Seattle" magazine, it's their "up-and-comers" issue -- the hottest hundred men and women in town.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, let me see.

speaker: Roz
text: Don't you want to finish up with Chester?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, you heard him, he can wait. [_flips through it_]

speaker: Roz
text: If you're looking for yourself, you're not in there.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh. [_keeps flipping_]

speaker: Roz
text: And your brother Niles isn't in there either.

speaker: Frasier
text: Cool! [_notices_] Oh, my.  Who is this fresh angel? Madeline Marshall, #47.

speaker: Roz
text: Ooh, manufactures her own line of sportswear!

speaker: Frasier
text: God, she's a stunning woman.  "Single, patron of the arts, MBA at Stanford" - well, if you have to go to school on the West Coast.  Oh, oh, oh, and what she looks for most in a man: "someone who knows how to... listen."  Roz, I'm in love!

speaker: Roz
text: Well, why don't you call her up and ask her out?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh yeah, right.

speaker: Roz
text: Well, I'm serious, Frasier!  What have you got to lose?

speaker: Frasier
text: I couldn't just call her out of the blue!  She doesn't even know who I am!

speaker: Roz
text: You're on the radio, a lot of people know who you are.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, well then why am I not in this magazine?

speaker: Roz
text: Because those are important people. [_picks up the phone_] Come on, I'll gonna call her up.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, no, no!

speaker: Bulldog
text: Hey, doc!

speaker: Frasier
text: Bulldog.

speaker: Bulldog
text: Just got back from the gym!  Did an hour on the Stairmaster! What do you think? [_turns around and slaps his buttocks_] Like a couple of little cherry tomatoes, huh?

speaker: Frasier
text: Thank you, Bulldog, you've just put me off salads for a month.

speaker: Bulldog
text: [_sees the magazine_] Hey, what have we got here?

speaker: Roz
text: Hello, is Madeline Marshall there?  Dr. Frasier Crane.

speaker: Bulldog
text: Whoa, whoa, whoa, wait a minute!  This Madeline Marshall, you know her?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, no, no, I found her attractive, and Roz insisted on calling her.

speaker: Bulldog
text: Wow, small wonder: smart, sophisticated, and I like a woman who doesn't wear underwear.

speaker: Frasier
text: She's wearing a business suit.

speaker: Bulldog
text: That was a general comment.

speaker: Roz
text: Hi, Miss Marshall?  Could you please hold for Dr. Crane? Thank you. _She pushes Hold and steps back.  She and Bulldog urge Frasier to pick up the phone._

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, all right.  "Once more unto the breach." [_picks up and punches line one_] Hello, this is Dr. Frasier Crane.  I know we've never met, but you know, from everything I know about you, you just seem like the most fascinating person.  I was just wondering if -- well, why don't I just come out and say it?  Would you be so good as to have dinner with me tonight? Oh well, well, that's very gracious of you to accept, Chester, but I didn't mean you. [_to Roz_] Roz, you could have told me Madeline was on line two!

speaker: Roz
text: You could have asked. _Frasier switches lines and tries again.  FADE OUT  Scene Two -- Apartment Daphne is writing a letter.  Martin is opening a box of authentic Cuban cigars. _

speaker: Daphne
text: Mr. Crane, is the proper term "serial killer" or "serial murderer?"

speaker: Martin
text: Serial killer, why?

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, just letting my old mum know what's going on in Seattle. She worries when she doesn't hear from me.

speaker: Martin
text: Hey Niles, how about a nice Havana to go with that wine?

speaker: Niles
text: Thank you! [_then_] Aren't Cuban cigars illegal?

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah, I got a friend in Customs over at Sea-Tac. He confiscated them from some high school teacher who claimed he was bringing them into the country for a civics lesson!  I mean, when are people going to learn?  Rules are only rules when they apply to everyone! [_N.B. Under the 1996 Helms-Burton Act, the fine for smuggling a single Cuban cigar into the United States is $35,000._]

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, I love to see a man with a cigar. [_Niles turns toward her, leaving Martin hanging_] It reminds me of my grandfather. Morning to night, he used to sit with a great big stogie dangling from his lips.  Oh, the hours we kids used to spend sitting on his lap, playing with the yellow whiskers beneath his nose.  Then he'd take out his teeth with the cigar still in them and chase us around the room!  We'd all laugh and laugh... then suddenly Grampa's mood would change and we'd all have to run for our lives.  You can't buy memories like that.

speaker: Frasier
text: Damn it!  Eddie, I know you took the socks that go with this suit.  Now where are they?

speaker: Frasier
text: Brown socks with a blue suit?  I think not, try again. [_Eddie pulls a pair of black ones from under the cushions_] Thank you.

speaker: Niles
text: And where are you off to?

speaker: Daphne
text: Dr. Crane has a blind date tonight.

speaker: Niles
text: Really, with who?

speaker: Frasier
text: Madeline Marshall.  She has her own sportswear concern, and according to "Seattle" magazine, she is the forty-seventh hottest person in Seattle.

speaker: Niles
text: That article was a sham.

speaker: Martin
text: Not in it, huh?

speaker: Niles
text: Can you believe it?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, well, I'm off!  You know, I have a good feeling about tonight.  I have a song in my heart, a little dance in my step, and dog saliva around my ankles! **BUSMAN'S HOLIDAY** _Scene Three -- Degas A small, quaint French gourmet restaurant.  Frasier and Madeline Marshall -- an attractive redhead in her thirties -- are seated. A young busboy brings them a basket of bread. _

speaker: Frasier
text: Thank you.

speaker: Madeline
text: This is wonderful!  I've never even heard of this place.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh well, my goodness, you're in for a treat.  Degas is the pinnacle of French country dining.  It's just Etienne Degas, his wife and daughter, and they'll treat us as if we were family.  Well, you know, I couldn't help being flattered when you told me that you knew my show.  Can I count you among my devoted listeners?

speaker: Madeline
text: Well, actually my secretary listens to it -- but I try to catch as much as I can when I cross back and forth through her office.

speaker: Etienne
text: Bonsoir, monsieur, madame, and welcome to Degas.  Our special tonight is our fabulous crispy duck!

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, yummy.  And to start off we'll have a bottle of the Chateau Neuf du Pape '89.

speaker: Madeline
text: Ah, the only one in that decade to outdo the '88.  That's the one to get!

speaker: Etienne
text: Ah, excellent choice! _As he leaves, he shakes a "Way to Go!" fist at Frasier, regarding Madeline._

speaker: Frasier
text: You know wine.

speaker: Madeline
text: Well, I try to make it a point to acquaint myself with the finer things in life.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh well, what would you like to know about me? [_laughs_]

speaker: Madeline
text: [_laughs, then_] Well, for starters, why is a man as charming as you still out there?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, actually, I... I'm recently divorced.

speaker: Madeline
text: Oh, thank goodness.  For a second there I thought you were one of those strange single men still living with his parents! [_laughs_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Yeah, yeah, your heart really has to go out to those sad sacks.

speaker: Madeline
text: I'm divorced also.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh well, we have so much in common.

speaker: Madeline
text: I caught him cheating with my sister.

speaker: Frasier
text: Fabulous! [_off her look_] The same thing happened to me.

speaker: Madeline
text: Boy, my sister gets around!

speaker: Frasier
text: It's good to see that you've still kept your sense of humor.

speaker: Madeline
text: Yeah, but it isn't easy to get over something like that, is it?

speaker: Frasier
text: No... no, it's not. [_sighs_] Those nights when you ask yourself how could this have happened?  Was I insensitive to her needs?

speaker: Madeline
text: Was I too devoted to my work?

speaker: Frasier
text: Was I simply not good enough in bed? [_off her look_] You'll reach for anything! _The busboy comes and fills their water glasses.  From the kitchen, the voices of the Degas family suddenly explode._

speaker: Etienne
text: [_o.s._] _Qu'est-ce que tu me racontes, alors?!_

speaker: Yvette
text: [_o.s._] No, Papa!

speaker: Etienne
text: What are you telling me, you are pregnant?!

speaker: Mrs. Degas
text: [_o.s._] Keep your voice down!

speaker: Yvette
text: [_crying_] I told you, Mama!  I told you he would be like this!

speaker: Etienne
text: Who is the father?!  I want to know!  _The busboy looks in panic towards the kitchen and he spills water as he is filling Frasier's glass, until Frasier stops him._

speaker: Etienne
text: Who is the father?!

speaker: Yvette
text: I won't tell you!

speaker: Etienne
text: Ha, ha, ha!  When I find this man, I will kill him! And snap his neck like a stale baguette! _The busboy flees the room as Etienne, all smiles, comes out with a bottle of wine._

speaker: Etienne
text: Monsieur, Madame, your wine.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, that's the one.

speaker: Etienne
text: _Bon, bon, bon_ , I will just go and open it.  Ah, this will be a night to remember, _non?_

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, yes!

speaker: Etienne
text: [_o.s._] Are you going to tell me?!

speaker: Yvette
text: [_o.s._] No, no!

speaker: Frasier
text: You know, there's a clam house up the road that has a late seating...

speaker: Madeline
text: Oh no, I think we're getting the most bang for our entertainment buck right here.

speaker: Mrs. Degas
text: [_o.s._] Oh, thirty-five years of marriage, what did I ever see in you?!

speaker: Etienne
text: Ah, you don't think I am sick of you?  You and your cuttlefish bisque!  I spit in your cuttlefish bisque! _The busboy huddles into a corner as Etienne, smiling again, comes out with two soup bowls and sets them before Madeline and Frasier._

speaker: Etienne
text: _Voila,_ monsieur, madame -- it's a delicacy from our little village in France: cuttlefish bisque.

speaker: Madeline
text: What are the odds?  I had cuttlefish for lunch.

speaker: Etienne
text: [_o.s._] Ah, no, no, no, you don't have to!  You can leave my house, Yvette!  No, no, no, go, go to wherever he is! _Mrs. Degas leads a tearful Yvette out of the kitchen.  By now, everyone's attention is on the unfolding drama._

speaker: Mrs. Degas
text: Pardon, monsieur, are you not the one who gives advice on the radio?

speaker: Frasier
text: You listen to my show?

speaker: Mrs. Degas
text: No, but my sous-chef does, and I hear you when I walk back and forth through the kitchen.  Monsieur, you must help me.  Etienne!

speaker: Frasier
text: No, no, listen, if-if everyone comes out here, how will you know when our duck is crispy?

speaker: Mrs. Degas
text: Etienne, this is the doctor from the radio, eh?

speaker: Etienne
text: Ah, _oui, oui, oui!_

speaker: Mrs. Degas
text: Please, monsieur, you must talk to my husband.  My daughter is with child, and he does not understand that these things happen!

speaker: Etienne
text: Don't talk to me, talk to this tramp! [_to Madeline_] Do you believe my daughter, madame?

speaker: Madeline
text: You should meet my sister.

speaker: Mrs. Degas
text: As if I wasn't pregnant when we got married, eh?

speaker: Etienne
text: Oh, I wish I had been killed in the war!

speaker: Mrs. Degas
text: Oh, it's hard to get killed when you run the other way!

speaker: Frasier
text: [_taking charge_] All right, _silence!  Silence!_  Both of you just try to calm down.  I'll see what I can do.  Monsieur Degas, you are angry now.  That is a temporary emotion. You are devastated because you think the bond between a father and a daughter has been broken.  She is no longer your little girl.  But that's not possible.  That bond cannot be broken -- not even by that young man cowering there in the corner who is so obviously the father.

speaker: Frasier
text: Come out. [_the busboy shakes his head_] Come out, it's all right. [_he still won't come_] We need more water!

speaker: Etienne
text: You?  You can't even get water in a glass! [_motions to Yvette_] How did you do this?! _Despite the embarrassing scrutiny, Yvette cannot help but gaze adoringly at her lover._

speaker: Frasier
text: Monsieur Degas, please -- hold your daughter in your arms and tell her how you really feel.

speaker: Etienne
text: [_takes her hands_] Yvette... ah, Yvette, Yvette, _ma petite_ , I love you... _They hug and kiss.  All the customers applaud, including Madeline. Etienne and Yvette go back to the kitchen.  Mrs. Degas hugs Frasier._

speaker: Mrs. Degas
text: Thank you, monsieur, thank you!  You are a god! [_to Madeline_] And you, mademoiselle, are very lucky.

speaker: Madeline
text: I'm starting to realize that.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_modestly_] Just another evening out... with Dr. Frasier Crane. _END OF ACT ONE  ACT TWO_ **LET'S GET AWAY FROM IT ALL** _Scene Four -- KACL Roz is checking the carts on the wall.  Frasier, ebullient, comes in._

speaker: Frasier
text: Hi, Roz!

speaker: Roz
text: Hey, Frasier.

speaker: Frasier
text: Again, thank you.

speaker: Roz
text: It's O.K., Frasier, you've thanked me every day for the last two weeks.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, yes, but if it hadn't been for you, I never would have met... [_sighs_] Madeline.  It's just -- you know, we went out again last night, and it's just perfect between us!  We talk, we can laugh at the same--

speaker: Roz
text: Just stop.  Did it ever occur to you that since I'm in one of the worst dating droughts of my entire adult life, that to hear you prattling on like a giggling schoolgirl about your storybook romance might be the teensiest bit irritating?

speaker: Frasier
text: No, it hadn't, and you're right, Roz.  I'm sorry, sometimes I can be so insensitive.  But, you know, Madeline's helping me with that, she is so good, she is so good, in, like, every way!

speaker: Frasier
text: All right, I'm sorry.  It's just that I haven't felt this way since, since my divorce.  Everything seems so right. You know, I haven't said this out loud, but here goes: it's possible that she could be the woman I spend the rest of my life with.

speaker: Roz
text: Go.  Go do that.  Get married, have a couple of kids, move out to the country, buy a puppy, live happily ever after! Just don't tell me about it, I need a boyfriend!

speaker: Frasier
text: Dear Roz.  Dear, silly Roz.  Dear, silly, horny Roz.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, oh, look!  It's--

speaker: Roz
text: That must be Madeline!

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes!

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, God, what a surprise to see you.

speaker: Madeline
text: Well, I hope you don't mind me stopping by, but I have a meeting with a buyer across the street in ten minutes, and there's something that I wanted to talk to you about.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh well, here, please, have a seat.

speaker: Madeline
text: [_sits in his chair_] Well, you know when we first started going out, we both agreed we didn't want to rush into the physical part, that we'd save ourselves for the right moment.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_looking around in surprise_] It's now?

speaker: Madeline
text: No, actually, uh, I was wondering what you thought about us going away for the weekend -- just the two of us.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, uh... I'd miss my favorite shows, but sure.

speaker: Madeline
text: I was thinking, two-three days... _They kiss.  The kiss gets deeper.  They throw their arms around each other, with Roz watching from the other side._

speaker: Frasier
text: I was thinking more like a week.

speaker: Madeline
text: O.K., now for the really big question: When?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, the minute we get there.

speaker: Madeline
text: No, actually, I meant when do we go?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, oh, let's see.

speaker: Madeline
text: Now, let's see, I am good for the week of the sixteenth.

speaker: Frasier
text: The, uh, sixteenth -- oh, no, sweeps week.  How about the twenty-third?

speaker: Madeline
text: Uh, no -- trade show.  Uh, thirtieth?

speaker: Frasier
text: No.

speaker: Madeline
text: That puts us into the next month.  No, no -- uh, the twentieth?

speaker: Frasier
text: No.

speaker: Madeline
text: Well, this was a great idea, but we're both obviously too busy.  We'll do it another time.  I got to run.

speaker: Frasier
text: O.K. _They kiss each other goodbye.  The kiss deepens again, and she drops her briefcase to the floor and they throw their arms around each other._

speaker: Frasier
text: Let's go tomorrow.

speaker: Madeline
text: You're on.

speaker: Frasier
text: I know the perfect place -- Bora Bora!

speaker: Madeline
text: Hubba Hubba!

speaker: Frasier
text: I'll make the arrangements.

speaker: Madeline
text: I'll meet you at the airport.

speaker: Frasier
text: O.K.

speaker: Madeline
text: O.K.  Bye.

speaker: Frasier
text: Bye. [_she heads out the producers' booth door_] Oh, oh, Madeline-- [_points her the other way_]

speaker: Madeline
text: Bye.

speaker: Roz
text: Hello, you don't know me, but I saw your picture in "Seattle" magazine... _FADE TO:  Scene Five -- Apartment That night, Niles and Martin are both relaxing with cigars. Martin leans against the piano, singing as Niles plays "I Don't Want To Walk Without You," finishing with a flourish. _

speaker: Martin
text: Ah, they don't write songs like that anymore.

speaker: Niles
text: This is really what "men" do, isn't it, Dad?

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah.  This, and some things outdoors, but we'll just stick to this for now.

speaker: Niles
text: You know, these last few nights have been very pleasant, Dad. You and me, sitting together, appreciating these fine cigars. Who would have thought a simple Cuban peasant somewhere in the Sierra Maestra would bring a father and son closer together?

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah.  Must make that dime he gets for a whole day's work a lot more satisfying.

speaker: Daphne
text: I'm going to miss these little sweethearts.

speaker: Martin
text: Ooh, now there's a talent.

speaker: Niles
text: [_mesmerized_] I'll say.  Just how do you do that?

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, it's really very simple.  Let me show you, it's all in the tongue. [_pulls him close and purses his lips with her fingers_] That's right, just purse your lips and pucker up like a little goldfish.  Just like that, you got it. _Frasier comes in and sees them -- nearly mouth-to-mouth, sticking their tongues toward each other's. _

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, what are you doing?

speaker: Niles
text: I'm learning how to blow smoke.

speaker: Frasier
text: Where?  Dad, I thought I asked you to smoke those things out on the balcony.

speaker: Martin
text: It's cold out there.

speaker: Frasier
text: Fine, all right.  Maybe an errant ash will flick off and ignite your easy chair.

speaker: Martin
text: You're in a fine mood.  What's the matter with you?

speaker: Frasier
text: Madeline and I are going to Bora Bora tomorrow.

speaker: Martin
text: [_sitting_] Why do bad things happen to good people?

speaker: Niles
text: When did this come about?

speaker: Frasier
text: Just about an hour ago, when Madeline came down to the station.  We got caught up in a moment of passion, before I know it I'm going halfway around the world with a woman I hardly even know!  It just isn't like me, I guess I'm getting caught up in the romance.

speaker: Daphne
text: Well, I'm not sure about the psychological ramifications of this, but it seems like a good thing to me.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, well, to the untrained eye, yes, but what if we hate each other?  End up being stuck together for a week!

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, that won't happen.  If anything, you'll come back even more in love than ever.

speaker: Frasier
text: Even worse!  If it goes perfectly, then it means we'll start talking about a serious commitment, then living together and then marriage, and...

speaker: Niles
text: If you ask me, Frasier, your trepidation is well-founded. It is possible to move a relationship along too fast, and ultimately marry too hastily.  You could find, a few years down the line, that the person isn't really right for you, [_more emphatic_] and then what happens if you meet the right person, someone who really excites you and makes you feel alive, but you can't act upon it because you're trapped in a stale, albeit comfortable Maris! [_everyone stares at him_] ...marriage.  I have to go now.

speaker: Martin
text: Hey, let me ask you one question, Frasier: did you feel a spark when you met this woman?

speaker: Frasier
text: Like fireworks.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, then go for it!  You know, these things don't happen that often.  It's like when I met your mother, it was at a crime scene.  Hester was a psychiatrist, so every now and again the department would have her run up a profile on a suspect.  I remember the first time I met her -- it was over the chalk outline of a murder victim.  She drew a little smile on the head of the outline, and I drew a pair of eyes, and before you knew it we were laughing like a couple of kids.

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, you're a ghoul.

speaker: Martin
text: I was joking.  We couldn't draw on the outline, they hadn't moved the body yet.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, well, your corpse-strewn romance notwithstanding, I still feel just a little bit skittish about this whole thing.

speaker: Daphne
text: Well, Dr. Crane, if you'd like a feminine point of view -- just shut your bloody cake hole and go!  I mean, look what happened when you took a chance and called this woman. You've been whistling a happy tune ever since.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, that is true.

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah!  So make another bold move!  Do something to make yourself happy.

speaker: Daphne
text: Yeah, go on!

speaker: Martin
text: Hey, you won't regret it!

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, all right, I'll do it!

speaker: Martin
text: Attaboy!  That's great, that's terrific!

speaker: Frasier
text: O.K., but don't think I don't know that you're mostly excited just to get me out of the house for a week!

speaker: Martin
text: It will be sweet, won't it? _Martin and Daphne sit back, savoring their cigars.  FADE TO:_ **PEOPLE WHO LIVE IN GRASS HOUSES** _Scene Six -- Bora Bora Frasier and Madeline enter their beachside bungalow.  In the background are the sounds of waves and tropical birds. _

speaker: Frasier
text: [_tipping the bellboy_] Thank you.

speaker: Madeline
text: This is gorgeous, I'm so glad you suggested it.

speaker: Frasier
text: It's even more beautiful than I remember.  You know what the natives say, they say that Bora Bora is the end of the world and the doorway to heaven.

speaker: Madeline
text: This could be the doorway to heaven for us.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_turns around_] I'm certainly glad that you're the one that said that first.  You know, I didn't want this to seem like our trip was just about sex, but... who are we kidding?

speaker: Madeline
text: I'm a little hot in these clothes, aren't you?

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm sweating like the pig that knows he's dinner!

speaker: Madeline
text: I'll be right back.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oink! _Madeline goes to the bathroom.  Frasier gets up, opens the door and goes out onto the balcony.  A woman in the adjacent bungalow is sunning herself in a deck chair with her back to Frasier.  Frasier breathes in the sea air.  Everything is just perfect.  Behind him, Madeline crosses the room wearing only a towel._

speaker: Madeline
text: Frasier...

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, my God...

speaker: Lilith
text: Frasier?

speaker: Frasier
text: OH, MY GOD! **TO BE CONTINUED...**
